headline.main: New From the Smoking Wars: Success

docs.abstract: Promising new approach for people trying to give up smoking involves combining antidepressant, nicotine replacement and counseling; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports when new approach was tried with 4,000 smokers, 40 percent to 60 percent remained smoke-free a year after completing program; fewer than 5 percent of smokers who seek to quit without outside help are successful; combination approach was first proposed by Dr Linda Ferry of Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Loma Linda, Calif; early results are being hailed by Dr C Everett Koop, former Surgeon General, and by Dr John Slade of American Society of Addictive Medicine; photos (M)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: A new approach combining an antidepressant, nicotine replacement and counseling is sharply increasing the chance of success among people who are trying to give up smoking. Typically, say scientists at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other experts on smoking, fewer than 5 percent of smokers who seek to quit without outside help are successful. But when the new approach was tried with 4,000 smokers at centers across the country, 40 percent to 60 percent remained smoke-free a year after completing the program.
